#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter III
#Text=Polly and Bingo always made the audience “ sit up ” when they swept into the ring .
#Text=She was so young , so gaily clad , so light and joyous in all her poses .
#Text=She seemed scarcely to touch the back of the white horse , as they dashed round the ring in the glare of the tent lights .
#Text=The other performers went through their work mechanically while Polly rode , for they knew the audience was watching her only .
#Text=As for Polly , her work had never lost its first interest .

#Text=Jim may have been right when he said that the spirit of the dead mother had got into her ; but it must have been an unsatisfied spirit , unable to fulfil its ambition in the body that once held it , for it sometimes played strange pranks with Polly .

#Text=To-night , her eyes shone and her lips were parted in anticipation , as she leaped lightly over the many coloured streamers of the wheel of silken ribbons held by Barker in the centre of the ring , and by Toby and the “ tumblers ” on the edge of the bank .
#Text=With each change of her act , the audience cheered and frantically applauded .
#Text=The band played faster ; Bingo 's pace increased ; the end of her turn was coming .
#Text=The “ tumblers ” arranged themselves around the ring with paper hoops ; Bingo was fairly racing .
#Text=She went through the first hoop with a crash of tearing paper and cheers from the audience .
#Text=“ Heigh , Bingo ! ” she shouted , as she bent her knees to make ready for the final leap .
#Text=Bingo 's neck was stretched .
#Text=He had never gone so fast before .
#Text=Barker looked uneasy .
#Text=Toby forgot to go on with his accustomed tricks .
#Text=Jim watched anxiously from the entrance .
#Text=The paper of one hoop was still left unbroken .
#Text=The attendant turned his eyes to glance at the oncoming girl ; the hoop shifted slightly in his clumsy hand as Polly leapt straight up from Bingo 's back , trusting to her first calculation .
#Text=Her forehead struck the edge of the hoop .
#Text=She clutched wildly at the air .
#Text=Bingo galloped on , and she fell to the ground , striking her head against the iron-bound stake at the edge of the ring .
#Text=Everything stopped .
#Text=There was a gasp of horror ; the musicians dropped their instruments ; Bingo halted and looked back uneasily ; she lay unconscious and seemingly lifeless .
#Text=A great cry went up in the tent .
#Text=Panic-stricken , men , women and children began to clamber down from their seats , while others nearest the ground attempted to jump into the ring .
#Text=Barker , still grasping his long whip , rushed to the girl 's side , and shouted wildly to Toby :
#Text=“ Say something , you .
#Text=Get ' em back ! ”
#Text=Old Toby turned his white face to the crowd , his features worked convulsively , but he could not speak .
#Text=His grief was so grotesque , that the few who saw him laughed hysterically .
#Text=He could not even go to Polly , his feet seemed pinned to the earth .
#Text=Jim rushed into the tent at the first cry of the audience .
#Text=He lifted the limp form tenderly , and kneeling in the ring held her bruised head in his hands .
#Text=“ Ca n't you get a doctor ! ” he shouted desperately to Barker .
#Text=“ Here 's the doctor ! ” some one called ; and a stranger came toward them .
#Text=He bent over the seemingly lifeless form , his fingers on the tiny wrist , his ear to the heart .
#Text=“ Well , sir ? ” Jim faltered , for he had caught the puzzled look in the doctor 's eyes as his deft hand pressed the cruelly wounded head .
#Text=“ I ca n't tell just yet , ” said the doctor .
#Text=“ She must be taken away . ”
#Text=“ Where can we take her ? ” asked Jim , a look of terror in his great , troubled eyes .
#Text=“ The parsonage is the nearest house , ” said the doctor .
#Text=“ I am sure the pastor will be glad to have her there until we can find out how badly she is hurt . ”
#Text=In an instant Barker was back in the centre of the ring .

#Text=He announced that Polly 's injuries were slight , called the attention of the audience to the wonderful concert to take place , and bade them make ready for the thrilling chariot race which would end the show .
#Text=Jim , blind with despair , lifted the light burden and staggered out of the tent , while the band played furiously and the people fell back into their seats .
#Text=The Roman chariots thundered and clattered around the outside of the ring , the audience cheered the winner of the race , and for the moment Polly was forgotten .
#Text=Chapter IV
#Text=THE blare of the circus band had been a sore temptation to Mandy Jones all afternoon and evening .
#Text=Again and again it had dragged her from her work to the study window , from which she could see the wonders so tantalisingly near .

#Text=Mandy was housekeeper for the Rev. John Douglas , but the unwashed supper dishes did not trouble her , as she watched the lumbering elephants , the restless lions , the long-necked giraffes and the striped zebras , that came and went in the nearby circus lot .
#Text=And yet , in spite of her own curiosity , she could not forgive her vagrant “ worse half , ” Hasty , who had been lured from duty early in the day .
#Text=She had once dubbed him Hasty , in a spirit of derision , and the name had clung to him .
#Text=The sarcasm seemed doubly appropriate to-night , for he had been away since ten that morning , and it was now past nine .
